prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MS AGNs COSMOS bright sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure CO(2-1) line fluxes for a sample of 5 AGNs at z~1.5 in the COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity.
a) We estimated the CO luminosity from the total infrared luminosity(LIR) in the 8-1000$\mu$m range following the Daddi et al. (2010) relation for star-forming galaxies in the main-sequence at z~1.5. We used this relation since our AGN sample has been selected exactly to be on the main-sequence of star-forming galaxies at that same redshift and it is more conservative than the Genzel et al. (2010) relation for SFGs (see Table 2). b) LIR is estimated from a direct fit to Herschel photometry. The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s, which corresponds to the median value for the FWHM of the CO(2-1) line observed in Daddi et al. (2010). c) A sensitivity of 0.5 mJy over a 400 km/s channel will assure a 3 sigma detection of the line for our faintest object in the sample (source C1148). In case of lower FWHM of the line core the detection will be even more significant. For the brighter objects in the sample the line will be detected with a higher S/N.
All the values described above are reported in Table 2.
Imaging requirements. We ask for a 1.6" resolution since the main goal of our project is to measure the total flux of the CO(2-1) line rather than resolving it and this set-up will give more flexibility while scheduling.
Correlator setup. We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~13 km/s. The four Basebands have been arranged to cover almost the two full sidebands allowing us to observe the CO(2-1) for several objects with the same tuning and therefore saving time on overheads to maximize the scientific output of ALMA time. In addition we will be able to sample also HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2) for a fraction of the sources
Standard calibrations are requested.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 12.5 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 40.8 minutes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Probing the properties of the molecular gas reservoir is a key ingredient of galaxy evolutionary studies: it is out of this gas that ultimately stars are formed. An open question is what is the role of black holes in the evolution of the gas content of their hosts. Previous CO studies of AGNs have been focused on bright quasars, whose hosts are well above the 'main-sequence'. But most of z>1 AGNs and star-forming galaxies are actually located in this 'main-sequence'. The main goal of this proposal is to use ALMA to address the scientic question: does the presence of an active SMBH affect the cold gas content of 'main-sequence' galaxies at z~1.5?. We propose to measure the CO(2-1) in a representative sample of 'main-sequence' z~1.5 AGNs. The measure will allow us to: a) Compare the star-formation efficiency of 'main-sequence' galaxies hosting AGNs with that of inactive galaxies and verify if AGN feedback is modifying the star-formation process in its host (e.g. positive feedback). b) Compare the gas fraction of these active galaxies with that measured for inactive galaxies and test if the molecular gas content in SMBHs hosts has changed due to AGN feedback.
